author: Conor Feehan, Alan O'Keeffe, Laura Larkin and Sam Griffin
title: Suicide killer guns down brave garda in cold blood and shoots partner
text:
An unarmed garda has been shot dead while attending a suspected domestic dispute that escalated into an apparent murder-suicide. Gda Tony Golden, a father-of three in his 30s, was gunned down by a dissident republican when he responded to a report of domestic violence at an address in Omeath, Co Louth.
Garda Tony Golden who was shot dead by a suspected IRA member in Omeath An ambulance leaves the scene in Omeath where Garda Tony Golden was shot dead after he was called to a domestic dispute Police close off a road in Omeath, Co Louth after two men, one of whom was a garda, were shot dead Police close off a road in Omeath, Co Louth after two men, one of whom was a garda, were shot dead Police close off a road in Omeath, Co Louth after two men, one of whom was a garda, were shot dead The incident happened between 6pm and 6.30pm after a row in a house in the Mullach Alainn estate. Gda Golden responded with colleagues.
READ MORE: Garda shot just a few miles from the scene of Donohoe murder
The gunman, named locally as Adrian Crevan Mackin (24), known to both the gardai and the PSNI as an active member of the IRA, shot Gda Golden.
An ambulance leaves the scene in Omeath where Garda Tony Golden was shot dead after he was called to a domestic dispute He also turned the handgun on his partner and killed himself.
The woman was described as being in a stable condition in hospital last night.
Worried
Police close off a road in Omeath, Co Louth after two men, one of whom was a garda, were shot dead The Herald understands that she reported a previous incident to gardai on Saturday which was being investigated.
READ MORE: Garda and male civilian shot dead, woman injured in incident in North County Louth
It is understood that a second incident flared in the house yesterday evening and the woman called gardai to say she was afraid her partner would kill her. Her worried relatives had also called the gardai.
Police close off a road in Omeath, Co Louth after two men, one of whom was a garda, were shot dead Mackin had been questioned about terrorist offences on a number of occasions and was charged with IRA membership before the Special Criminal Court in January.
He had been arrested following a number of searches carried out in Dundalk and Newry as part of a joint garda and PSNI investigation into the activities of dissident republicans. He was subsequently granted bail in the High Court.
Gda Golden was a highly respected member of the force with more than 10 years' service.
Originally from Co Mayo, he previously served in the now-closed Kill O' the Grange Station in south Dublin and was later transferred to Louth.
Patrol cars blocked off all access to the housing estate last night, and only gardai and residents were allowed access.
Fr Christy McElwee said the small community was trying to come to terms with the terrible tragedy.
"Talking to local people, they are not familiar with this type of incident, they can't believe that this is happening in their community," he said.
"The situation is so shocking, especially as it involved a local guard who everybody knows and liked, a fine family man. It's a very sad story."
Sympathy
President Michael D Higgins expressed his sympathy to the family of Gda Golden and discussed the incident with Garda Commissioner Noirin O'Sullivan.
"I have contacted the Commissioner to express my deepest sympathies on this terrible loss of a young member of the force while doing his duty on behalf of the State and all of society," said Mr Higgins."I want to express my deepest sympathy to the family and friends of the garda who has so tragically lost his life while responding to this incident.
"My thoughts at this time are also with all others who have been affected by the events in Omeath earlier this evening."
Commissioner O'Sullivan said: "I am deeply saddened to hear of the death of my colleague in a fatal shooting incident this evening while carrying out their duties.
"At this time my thoughts and prayers and those of the entire garda service are with his family, friends and colleagues.
"This incident highlights the unique nature of the job carried out by the men and women of An Garda Siochana, and the dangers they face every day."
Justice Minister Frances Fitzgerald said: "The fact that a garda has laid down his life while protecting the community is a cause of great sadness.
"His death will be mourned by the entire nation, grateful for the service which he gave to it."
Garda Representative Association president Dermot O'Brien said his members are "shocked and saddened by the awful news that a colleague in Omeath has been shot and killed".
"This dreadful, dreadful news is the deepest fear of every police family," he said.
"This puts everything we do into perspective.
"At this time of distress, the garda family will be doing everything possible to support the late garda's relatives and loved ones, friends and colleagues."
